An Orange County woman is desperately searching for the return of her beloved wedding dress that was accidentally donated to a local Goodwill.  Rebecca Nguyen Sanchez/Facebook  Rebecca Nguyen was wearing a beautiful classic lace gown adorned with beading and spaghetti straps when she married the love of her life in August 2017. In the years since, the dress has acted as a reminder of the magical day.  "When I wore it, I felt like me," Nguyen said. "I want to say I felt like this movie star. I felt like this princess, but that wasn't me. I felt like me."  The memories of that dream quickly turned into a nightmare on Tuesday, when she received the shock of her life, learning that her dress was suddenly missing.  "My wedding dress was accidentally donated by one of my family members. It was a complete accident, it was during a rush of a lot of things," she said while speaking with KCAL News on Wednesday. "Mistakes happen. When I found out yesterday I was pretty heartbroken."  Nguyen says that the dress wasn't the only wedding souvenir that got donated to a Goodwill in Brea more than two weeks ago, and she immediately submitted an accidental donation form in hopes of retrieving what she could.  She's visited Goodwill's Orange County headquarters, hoping that some of the employees could help her recover the lost items.  "It could be sitting at the warehouse, still waiting to get sorted through," said Chris Sewitsky, the retail director at the location. "It just depends where and what time of day it came in. That store is a very busy store. Some stuff does stay at that store, some stuff comes back to main distribution. So, we're hoping we can find it because it is such a unique item."  On top of her local search, Nguyen has also posted on several local Facebook pages offering to buy back the dress if it's already been purchased.  "If you have it, please consider selling it back to me. I will pay more than you paid for it. You can even wear it for your wedding! I don't mind sharing the joy and beauty of the dress," one post says.  If someone does have it, she's hopeful that they're able to get as much enjoyment out of their special day as she did.  "Not everybody can afford to get a brand new dress and that's okay. I want someone to be able to enjoy it as well," Nguyen said.  Anyone with more information on the missing dress can reach out to Goodwill in Brea, which is located at 634 S. Brea Boulevard, by calling (714) 255-1099.

As you're planning your wedding, you likely want to craft a celebration that you'll love looking back on for years to come. The best way to organize a timeless event is to host classic affair with plenty of design details that have already proven they can stand the test of time. "Picking wedding d√©cor and fashion can be daunting, especially if you want your wedding to feel timeless," shares wedding planner Dani Blasena of HauteF√™tes. "While Instagram and Pinterest are wonderful for inspiration, they often promote the same trending ideas over and over again. In contrast, a timeless wedding is one that stands the test of time and style!" So, if you want to plan a timeless ceremony and reception, it's best to choose color palettes, fashion, and d√©cor that will still feel relevant in 20 years.  It's important to remember that timeless weddings can take many forms, so don't shy away from the style out of fear of planning a cookie cutter celebration. You can still infuse the day with plenty of personality. "For me, what makes a wedding timeless is not about following the most current wedding trends or guidelines but about creating a celebration that genuinely reflects a couple's unique love story and values," notes wedding photographer Jenny Fu. "It's about making an impact that lasts long after the day."  Meet the Expert Dani Blasena is the owner, creative director and lead designer of HauteF√™tes.  Jenny Fu is a New York-based wedding photographer.  Jacqueline Hallgarth is the founder of wedding and event planning company Jacqueline Hallgarth Events.  If you're hoping to plan a timeless wedding that feels right for you and your spouse-to-be, we asked wedding pros to share their favorite details. Ahead, 20 ideas you can make your own.  Photo by KT Merry; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Choose a Classic Destination  ‚ÄúVenue selection is one of the most important aspects of creating a timeless wedding,‚Äù shares planner Jacqueline Hallgarth. If you know you want to tie the knot far from home, consider a locale that's steeped in history. ‚ÄúYou and your guests will be linked forever through this selection, so choose carefully," she adds. "A destination wedding, held in historic villa in Italy or chateau in France, will not only be beautiful on your wedding day, but will also create timeless memories shared by you and all your guests. Regardless of the specific venue, beautiful memories can be created anywhere with the right elements.‚Äù  Photo by Caroline Tran; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Pick an Estate-Style Venue  Modern art galleries and open warehouses are incredible blank slates, but they're not the best choices for timeless celebrations. ‚ÄúChoosing an estate-style venue that is classic in architecture and will create a backdrop for your big day that is as relevant in 20 years‚Äô time as it is today,‚Äù advises Blasena. ‚ÄúMy favorites include Rosewood Miramar Beach for a classic Hamptons style on the West Coast replete with boxwoods and white siding. Abroad, the Belmond San Michele with views for days, classic Italian-style spaces and gardens that are breathtaking. Both venues have everything you need to make your big day truly timeless from start to finish.‚Äù  Photo by Will Reid Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Have a Black-Tie Dress Code  What your guests wear will have an impact on the overall feel of your celebration, so picking the right attire style is important. ‚ÄúBy requesting black-tie and formal attire, you automatically create an elevated style that translates into forever cherished photographs,‚Äù shares Hallgarth. "Floor-length gowns and black tuxedos never go out of fashion and when captured together, creates that timeless look everyone wants from their wedding.‚Äù  Photo by Volvoreta; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Choose Greenery and White Florals  When picking out your floral design, you can never go wrong with classic white blooms and lots of lush greenery. Blasena says, ‚ÄúGreen and white flowers are both classic and neutral and will never overwhelm a design.‚Äù  Photo by Stephanie Sunderland; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Embrace a Soft Color Palette  Punchy colors might be trending, but are you sure you'll love Barbie pink or neon green for years to come? If the answer isn't a resounding "yes!" it's likely not the best choice. ‚ÄúA soft color palette is always a good rule of thumb," notes Blasena. "Something like a French blue or classic taupe is always sophisticated and elegant. Pick two to three soft colors that suit your style best and keep it simple.‚Äù  Photo by Ryan Ray; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Hire the Right Wedding Photographer  You could plan a big day that's entirely timeless, but if you hire a photographer with a trendy, of-the-moment aesthetic, your photos might not stand the test of time. "To truly capture the timeless essence of a wedding, it's crucial to work with an experienced photographer who can document your day,‚Äù shares Fu. ‚ÄúThe photographs they capture will be a lasting reminder of the love and joy you shared on your wedding day.‚Äù Blasena adds, ‚ÄúA photographer with a classic editing style, natural color tones, and graceful composition will create photographs never go out of style.‚Äù  Photo by Lev Kuperman; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  And Don't Shy Away from Candid Photos  While traditional wedding portraits are essential, some couples avoid candids out of fear of looking too modern. Whatever you do, get this idea out of your head. "Candid wedding photographs have the power to capture the true essence and emotion of your wedding day," says Fu. "Let the genuine connections and meaningful moments shine‚Äìthese moments are timeless because you've lived the experience, and the candid photographs can take you back long after the day has passed."  Photo by Henry + Mac; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Wear Classic Wedding Attire  Fashion trends come and go, even in the world of weddings. ‚ÄúOne of the most important elements of your wedding is your dress,‚Äù says Blasena. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easy to get caught up in all the amazing wedding fashion there is today with designers from all over the world. To avoid looking back in horror, think timeless and classic in the cut; a soft ivory versus a stark white; and, avoid overcomplicating the style with unnecessary embellishments such as beading, tulle, or lace. Remember, less is always more!‚Äù  Photo by Lisa Poggi; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Have Musicians at Your Ceremony  Acoustic versions of your favorite romantic songs can bring an emotional elegance and set the proper tone for your wedding ceremony. Consider hiring a string trio or a classical guitarist to play as you walk down the aisle.  Photo by Benjamin Wheeler and Ben Higgins; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Close Out the Ceremony With a Flower Petal Toss  Add an extra dose of joy and ensure excellent photos of your ceremony exit by having guests toss flower petals over your heads as you recess down the aisle as newlyweds.  Photo By Twah Dougherty; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Decorate With Chinoiserie  A classic d√©cor choice for a wedding is to bring chinoiserie ceramics into your design. Used as vessels for your florals or in your dinnerware, it adds a traditional and elegant touch to the space.  Photo by Haley Rynn Ringo; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Have a Champagne Tower  Serving Champagne is a classic choice for a wedding. Serve your favorite bubbly in coupes, stacked in a tower, to make for an extra celebratory (and photo-worthy) moment at your reception.  Photo by AGP Collective; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Set Up a Checkered Dance Floor  A checkered dance floor is a classic for a reason. It sets the tone for the reception and brings a retro elegance as you get down with your new spouse and guests.  Photo by Corbin Gurkin; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Embrace Candlelight  ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs dinner for two or a wedding for 250, candlelight creates an intimate atmosphere which can transform any space,‚Äù shares Blasena. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing more magical than a candlelit room to create romance. Adding clusters of pillar and votive candles or simple white taper candles to your tabletop is an inexpensive touch that will also never go out of style.‚Äù  Photo by An√©e Atelier; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Opt for Black-and-White Photos  Don‚Äôt forget to ask your photographer to edit some shots without color. ‚ÄúBlack and white photography is classic, timeless, and elegant. It creates a sophisticated look that will never go out of style,‚Äù says Fu.  Photo by Jenny Fu; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Consider Seasonal Shades  ‚ÄúFeaturing seasonal colors in the floral, stationery, tabletop and event design creates an event that resonates with guests emotions and ties your wedding to a place in time,‚Äù shares Hallgarth. "I always encourage bright and colorful blooms for a spring wedding and autumnal florals and foliage for a fall wedding which captures not only the beauty of the moment, but forever marries the event to a specific feeling of the year.‚Äù  Photo by Brooke Miller Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Have a Getaway Car  After you say ‚ÄúI do,‚Äù there‚Äôs nothing more timeless than speeding off into the sunset with your new spouse. Find a vintage car and adorn it with florals for a charming getaway for the newlyweds as they head to the reception.  Photo by Sasithon Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Make a Grand Entrance  As the wedding reception begins, have a special moment where the emcee announces the bride and groom for the first time as they rush out onto the dance floor. The entrance is a fun and celebratory moment that can easily transition to the first dance, and it's something that's been done at weddings for decades.  Photo by Allan Zepeda Photography; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Hire a Live Band  While choosing a DJ or band for your wedding is a personal decision for a couple, there's no denying that live musicians can be an absolutely classic addition to your celebration. Make sure to do research to have your band fit the style and song selection you want for the evening.  Photo By Tailor James; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Leave With a Sparkler Exit  At the end of the evening (or before you head to the after party), have your guests line up for a sparkler send-off. It's a beautiful end to celebrations around those you love.

A TikToker called Madison Mulkey went viral after she said she served Chili's at her wedding.  The comments were mostly positive, although some questioned whether staff were properly compensated.  In a follow-up video, Mulkey said she tipped the staff ‚Äî though some users still raise doubts.  Top editors give you the stories you want ‚Äî delivered right to your inbox each weekday. Loading Something is loading. Thanks for signing up! Access your favorite topics in a personalized feed while you're on the go. download the app Email address By clicking ‚ÄòSign up‚Äô, you agree to receive marketing emails from Insider as well as other partner offers and accept our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy  A bride went viral with a TikTok video about serving Chili's at her wedding, framing it as a unique and cost-efficient option. The response was generally positive, with many applauding the idea and saying they wished they had thought of it themselves.  She also received curious questions and some criticism about whether it imposed extra work on her wedding staff, which prompted her to make a follow-up video saying that she tipped all service workers involved. Despite her attempted clarification, some viewers were unconvinced and alleged that she deleted a previous comment saying she hadn't tipped them.  Still, the apparent hack has inspired others to think more creatively about wedding food ‚Äî so as long as restaurant and ceremony workers are properly compensated.  Mulkey did not immediately respond to multiple requests from Insider for comment.  Madison Mulkey, a photographer with over 28,000 TikTok followers, posted a video on Sunday explaining why she chose the restaurant chain Chili's for her wedding food.  She said the main attraction was the low cost ‚Äî $1,950 for 99 guests. The food included chicken tenders, sliders, cajun chicken pasta, and salad. According to The Knot, the average price for traditional wedding catering can cost $75 a guest, which for Mulkey, amounted to nearly $7,500 total.  She said there were some unexpected complications that arose because they didn't want to pay the delivery fee ‚Äî which would have been $300, she said in a comment. They threw their wedding on St. Patrick's Day weekend, and the restaurant was packed, so they had to pick up the food early at 11 a.m. and keep it cool before the service which was at 6 p.m.  Normally, Chili's workers would deliver and set it up, Mulkey said. But since they picked the food up directly from the restaurant, her hired servers ‚Äî who were mostly hired for cleaning, she said ‚Äî were forced to do a lot of the food preparations. She added that her coordinator helped them.  "Everyone made it work, thank goodness," Mulkey said in the clip, which has been viewed over 1.3 million times. "Our situation was rare. I'm sure if you order from Chili's in any other regard they would serve it and it would all be so hassle-free."  The reaction was mostly positive, with people saying they would be excited to find out a wedding they attended was serving Chili's, and that society should normalize scaled-down weddings like this.  "I would be so hype to find out the wedding food was chili's," a top comment with over 7,000 likes said. "This is my dream," someone else wrote.  The official Chili's Grill & Bar TikTok account even left a comment calling the video "iconic."  However, some people worried that Mulkey's wedding staffers were forced to take on more work.  "I'm all for this, but as someone who works in the industry, this sounds like a nightmare for your staff and coordinator," one top comment with over 1,600 likes said. "You should have paid for delivery."  A comment with over 2,200 likes said they'd give the poster an "A for creativity" but critiqued that the food was 7 hours old, which probably stressed the staff out.  The concerns for her staff prompted Mulkey to make a follow-up video. She assured viewers that she tipped the Chili's kitchen staff $300, and tipped the coordinator and the servers on top of their hourly payment.  "All they did was make the food, help the buffet run efficiently, and then clean up," Mulkey said of the servers. "I didn't ask anyone to work outside of their bounds or their means."  Viewers, however, did not seem entirely convinced. Several comments on the follow-up video accused her of deleting a comment from her original viral video where they said she told another user she hadn't tipped anyone extra since it was included in their original payment (Insider was unable to find and verify the original comment).  Someone also claimed that Chili's managers aren't able to receive tips which prompted them to ask how she was able to tip them. (Insider could not independently verify this but has reached out to the company for comment.)  "Maybe they didn't take it, I have no idea what they did with it," Mulkey wrote in response. "We gave chilis a lump sum."

If you're running out of unique venues or destinations to have your wedding, look no further. Weddings in space are now a thing and we heard it is truly out of this world.  If the thought of nuptials on Earth sound common and boring, a space travel company wants to give you the chance to get hitched at a venue looking down on the third rock from the sun instead.  The company, called Space Perspective, is offering couples a memorable way to say ‚ÄúI do‚Äù ‚Äî putting the bride and groom into orbit using a carbon-neutral balloon with giant windows to make the most of the ultimate view of planet Earth.  According to Jane Poynter, the co-founder of Space Perspective, the waiting list to get married amongst the stars is already light-years long.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve already had people wanting to be the first marriage in space, so we‚Äôll see who is the first,‚Äù Poynter told The Cool Down.  ‚ÄúUnlike all other spacecraft whereby the crewed compartment separates from one flight system mid-flight and transfers to another flight system, Spaceship Neptune‚Äôs capsule remains secured to the SpaceBalloon the entire flight from liftoff to splashdown, creating a seamlessly safe and gentle flight,‚Äù she explained.  The website said the technology the spacecraft uses has already been ‚Äúproven,‚Äù as it has been used for decades by NASA teams and other government agencies to ‚Äúlift research telescopes and other heavy, sensitive instruments.‚Äù  Space Perspective was founded by two former crew members of Biosphere 2, an Earth system science research facility located in Arizona, which was originally constructed to explore the potential of closed ecological systems in supporting human life during outer-space missions.  Vincent Bachet, Space Perspective lead and development engineer, added that Neptune‚Äôs windows are going to be ‚Äúthe biggest windows flown into space.‚Äù  Using hyper-resistant materials and a special anti-UV coating, Space Perspective co-founder and co-CEO Taber MacCallum called them ‚Äúthe quintessential part of the experience.‚Äù  Couples who are interesting in the unique wedding experience can join the waitlist on Space Perspective‚Äôs website for late 2024.  Source: NY Post
Why, you might ask? Well, according to Olivia, it had everything to do with the speech she made at the ceremony.

If you asked Carolina Favero Braga if she would end up with Freud Milice as she began her emergency room rotation in 2015, her answer would likely be a resounding no. The twosome worked alongside each other for two weeks at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn when she was a medical school student and he was a resident. As Carolina puts it, their courtship wasn‚Äôt exactly love at first sight. ‚ÄúI was skeptical of his big personality and braggadocios behavior,‚Äù Carolina admits. ‚ÄúOn our first few days working together, he told me he loved house parties, red wine, and older women. Eye roll.‚Äù  But, in a plot twist of romantic comedy proportions, Freud managed to get Carolina‚Äôs number and would text her after every shift‚Äîand even when she traveled to Florida. ‚ÄúOn the day I was returning to New York, he knew I was anxious about flying, and sent me Angus and Julia Stone‚Äôs ‚ÄòBig Jet Plane‚Äô single to keep me calm throughout the flight. When I landed at JFK, he surprised me and was waiting at baggage claim. Five days later, we went on our first official date. As they say, the rest is history.‚Äù  Fast-forward to June 5, 2020, when the couple was taking a socially distanced trip to the Catskills. As physicians, both Carolina and Freud were on the frontlines of the Covid-19 pandemic and took a well-deserved vacation once restrictions began to loosen. ‚ÄúWhen we arrived, the hotel staff recommended a walk in the garden prior to dinner,‚Äù she shares. ‚ÄúWe got ready and while walking the garden, Freud got down on one knee. I am sure he had more to say but all I remember is, ‚ÄòWill you marry me?‚Äô‚Äù The answer? A resounding yes.  When it came to planning their September 3, 2022, wedding, the couple wanted their special day to highlight the bride‚Äôs Brazilian background and the groom‚Äôs Haitian roots. They enlisted wedding planner Nathalie Cadet-James of Luxe Fete, who had the perfect spot in mind: Itapororoca Villa in Trancoso, Brazil. ‚ÄúThere is the essence of West Africa in this rustic Brazilian beach town,‚Äù the bride explains. ‚ÄúWith its scenic backdrops and rich culture, we knew this was the perfect place to share our love story with family and friends.‚Äù  With 80 of their closest friends and family members in attendance, their destination was a beautiful representation of Carolina and Freud in every way imaginable. ‚ÄúAs an interracial couple, it was important for us to highlight our different backgrounds,‚Äù the bride shares. ‚ÄúNathalie is Haitian-American, and she really understood who we were as individuals, but also as a couple. Her excitement to celebrate our love story was noticeable from before we even officially hired her.‚Äù Read on for an intimate look at Carolina and Freud‚Äôs wedding festivities, as photographed by Heather Waraksa.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Carolina and Freud didn‚Äôt have to look too far for wedding inspiration. Elements of Trancoso‚Äôs seaside beauty were woven throughout the weekend. From watercolor illustrations to magenta accents that pay tribute to the local bougainvillea flowers, the invitation suite from LetterHeads Miami gave guests the perfect glimpse of what was to come.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  The couple kicked off the festivities with a beach party the night before the wedding. Carolina stunned in a white dress from Farm Rio, while Freud looked effortlessly elegant in a white button-down from Peter Millar and matching shorts.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  ‚ÄúOur wedding [weekend] didn‚Äôt have a traditional timeline,‚Äù the bride shares. ‚ÄúWe had our maid of honor and best man make their speeches during the welcome party so they could enjoy themselves. We know the effort it took for our guests to celebrate with us and we wanted them to enjoy themselves to the fullest.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  I don‚Äôt know how to describe it, but I knew the dress was made for me.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Come the wedding day, the bride wore a strapless gown from Valentini Spose, which beautifully fulfilled her ‚Äúclean and timeless vision.‚Äù She shares, ‚ÄúI truly believed that this was my day and wanted to wear something that made me feel spectacular. I was also three months postpartum when I started shopping for a wedding dress, so it was important for me to feel confident in it." Carolina adds, "I don‚Äôt know how to describe it, but I knew the dress was made for me.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  When it came to accessorizing her gown, Carolina knew she wanted to support women-owned businesses. She opted for a veil by Jennifer Leigh Couture Veils, Julia Vaughn jewelry, and a special pair of shoes from Brother Vellies. ‚ÄúDuring the beginning of the pandemic, I followed [Brother Vellies founder] Aurora James on Instagram,‚Äù Carolina explains. ‚ÄúIt had to be fate that [she] designed a bridal shoe line for HBO‚Äôs Insecure. I texted Nathalie and the team and said, ‚ÄòI know I don‚Äôt have a dress yet, but I know this is the shoe.‚Äô So, I actually bought my bridal shoes before I had a dress!‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Meanwhile, the groom suited up in a custom navy tuxedo from Suitsupply. Rounding out the look was a tie from Tom Ford, Herm√®s shoes, and his everyday accessories. ‚ÄúFreud wore his watch and a bracelet which was engraved with his daughter‚Äôs name,‚Äù Carolina adds.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Prior to the ceremony, the couple had an ‚Äúintimate and emotional‚Äù first look. ‚ÄúWe wanted to have a moment between us before sharing ‚Äòus‚Äô with everyone else,‚Äù the groom explains.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Upon arrival, guests could grab some water, local juices, or a monogrammed coconut as they listened to a soothing setlist from the string quartet group Quarteto De Cordas de Trancoso.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  ‚ÄúOur ceremony was on the beach underneath coconut trees with a wooden altar decorated with bougainvillea,‚Äù the bride shares. ‚ÄúIt was very simple, but elegant at the same time.‚Äù The view of the ocean was a welcomed bonus.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Carolina glided down the aisle to Felix Mendelssohn‚Äôs ‚ÄúMarcha Nupcial,‚Äù with her father and a bouquet of local flowers in tow.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Freud spent months writing his vows during his night shifts, promising to ‚Äúbe present, to be here next week, next month, next year, and the year after that.‚Äù Meanwhile, Carolina performed a song she often sings to their daughter at night. Her favorite lyrics: ‚ÄúI love you in the morning, and in the afternoon. I love you in the evening, and underneath the moon.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  The newlyweds slipped on their wedding bands from Boccardo Jewelers, shared a kiss, and recessed down the aisle to Bob Marley‚Äôs ‚ÄúIs This Love.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Make time to enjoy special moments with each other. It goes by so fast!  Photo by Heather Waraksa  After the ceremony, Carolina and Freud snuck away to take some pictures with photographer Heather Waraksa. ‚Äú‚Äã‚ÄãMake time to enjoy special moments with each other,‚Äù the couple recommends. ‚ÄúIt goes by so fast!‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  ‚ÄúOur reception decor is what [our florist] Katia Criscuolo calls 'brasilidade sofisticada'‚Äîor 'sophisticated Brazilianness,'‚Äù Carolina shares. ‚ÄúShe incorporated local materials and tones in the lighting, linens, and place setting. There was one long table in the reception area with no assigned seating, which was to be decorated with magenta flowers among greenery.‚Äù The bride‚Äôs favorite area was the dessert room‚Äîa bougainvillea-adorned space that displayed ‚Äúhundreds of sweets‚Äù on floating trays.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  If guests were craving fresh air, they could hang out in one of the venue‚Äôs chill outdoor seating areas.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  True to their love story, Carolina and Freud shared a sweet first dance to Angus and Julia Stone‚Äôs ‚ÄúBig Jet Plane.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  While the newlyweds opted for a buffet style of local Bahian-inspired food‚Äîcourtesy of O Cacau‚Äîthey tapped Confet Doceria to whip up a four-tiered cake. ‚ÄúWe had two different flavors. One layer was white cake with brigadeiro filling, [which is a traditional Brazilian dessert],‚Äù the bride explains. ‚ÄúThe other layers were white cake with dulce de leche filling.‚Äù  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Photo by Heather Waraksa  Since Carolina and Freud love music‚Äîthey have a shared fondness of hip-hop‚Äîthey wanted to find a DJ who understood their taste. ‚ÄúWe worked closely with our DJ, Nath Carreiro, to play music that played significant parts in our lives both as individuals and as a couple,‚Äù the groom notes. "We shared with her Spotify playlists for both the welcome party and the wedding. DJ Nath was a smashing success!" In fact, the newlyweds even infiltrated the DJ booth during the evening with their daughter, Celine.  Photo by Heather Waraksa  ‚ÄúWe were on the dance floor for most of the wedding,‚Äù Freud explains. But, according to the couple, guests left the event with more than some new dance moves. ‚ÄúBecause many of our friends had never been to Brazil before, we focused a high level of detail on the experience that our guests would have,‚Äù Carolina shares. ‚ÄúFreud created a WhatsApp group with all the guests as a way for everyone to connect a few weeks prior to the wedding. Our guests were able to get to know each other and it made it even more special on the wedding day. The group is still going strong to this day!‚Äù Whether it‚Äôs an inner circle or excellent vendors, no love story is complete without the people cheering you on along the way.

Be the best dressed wedding guest with these looks  E! Style host Zanna Roberts Rassi shares the hottest looks as you prepare to attend your next wedding ‚Äî whether it's black tie, cocktail attire or a destination!May 17, 2023

A couple set to get married in June says their wedding guests were kicked out of an upstate New York hotel to make room for migrants .  Gary Moretti and Deanna Mifsud booked their dream wedding in Lippincott Manor and had reserved a block of 30 rooms for guests to stay at The Crossroads Hotel nearby in Newburgh, New York. They reportedly expected 160 guests from across the country to attend their June 24 wedding.  The couple says their plans were turned upside down when they learned their hotel block had been cancelled to make room for migrants that were being sent upstate by New York City Mayor Eric Adams. The Crossroads Hotel was tapped to accept migrants who were being bused from New York City to hotels in Westchester and the Hudson Valley.  "We woke up the other morning and got a phone call from my sister...to check out the news," Moretti told " Jesse Watters Primetime " on Tuesday. "No phone call, no text message, no email from them about any cancellations. I call them up and ... I asked them about the migrants going in there, is it going to be safe for my guests and ourselves to be there. They said, ‚ÄòNo, you have nothing to worry about‚Äô and in my heart I'm thinking, ‚ÄòOK, cool.‚Äô They‚Äôre like... ‚ÄòYour contract has been cancelled.'"  REDDIT USER SLAMMED FOR PLANNING TO ATTEND A TAYLOR SWIFT CONCERT INSTEAD OF HER OWN MOTHER'S WEDDING  The couple said hotel officials told them there was nothing they could do, and it was a "complete madhouse" in there. The soon-to-be newlyweds were instructed to contact Choice Management, which oversees the hotel. They said they played a "back and forth game" talking to The Crossroads Hotel and Choice, to no avail. Now they are scrambling to find accommodations for their quickly approaching wedding .  CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP  Mifsud said the couple‚Äôs venue, which has no connection to the hotel, has been "awesome" and is trying to help them draft ideas where to stay, but it has been met with challenges.  "It's also the air show weekend," she told "Jesse Watters Primetime." "So, everything is completely sold out. The hotels that are even talking to us with possible rooms, they want to charge us anywhere from like $300 to $400 a night. Now, our transportation, everybody (is) going to be scattered. So, we have one hotel that has been doing great. We have about 15 rooms blocked with them, but...we don't have a place to go. We're looking at Airbnbs."

Derek Hough and Hayley Erbert are headed towards the altar, while balancing expectations of their wedding day.  In a new interview in Brides magazine, the Dancing with the Stars alum, who turns 38 on Wednesday, and his fianc√©e, 28, revealed that the price of planning a wedding has come as a bit of a shock.  "It's a very eye-opening experience, and when you start to add everything up, it's pretty wild," Hough said.  As the pieces for their ceremony and reception come together, the couple revealed that they have already chosen a venue, and that fireworks and a first dance ‚Äî naturally ‚Äî are in the cards.  For the choreographer and actor, and his dancer bride-to-be, the wedding isn't so much about "perfection" as it is about a "vibe," which is important when it comes to the guest list.  "A rule that we've set is that we don't want to catch up with people on the day of the wedding," Erbert said. "We're inviting people that maybe we haven't seen in a while, but every time we get together with them, it's like we pick up right where we left off, or they're people that have been consistently in our lives throughout the years. We're not going to catch up with people, we're just gonna have a blast with people."  Amy and Stuart Photography for Brides  Never miss a story ‚Äî sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.  The couple, who got engaged last June after a seven-year courtship, intend to have a wedding celebration that perfectly reflects who they are.  "We're fun!" Hough said. "What we gravitate towards isn't always the most lavish option. We're playing with different approaches to certain things so that the day still feels elegant and beautiful and magical, but grounded and down to earth and just approachable."  He added, "We want the entire day to be a blast."  And as for that first dance, Erbert revealed that it will be a special moment, even if Hough wasn't so interested in the wedding tradition at first.  "We perform for a living, so we just want this dance to be for us," she said. "We don't want to perform for anyone else."  Adds Hough: "We want to feel good and comfortable, but we don't need to be perfect‚Ä¶ That's a lot less important to me than just looking into her eyes as we're rocking back and forth. I want to feel truly present in that moment."  As the big day draws near, Hough said that the couple has remained grounded and focused on what's really important.  "At the end of the day we come back to, 'Why are we doing this? What is the reason for this?'" Hough said. "And the reason is for the two of us. That's really it."

A newlywed widower whose bride died in a golf-cart crash after the couple's wedding reception last month has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the alleged drunken driver charged in her death.  The suit, filed Wednesday in South Carolina's Ninth Judicial Circuit Court of Common Pleas by Aric Hutchinson and two other people hurt in the crash, names more than a half dozen defendants including Jamie Lee Komoroski, who police arrested in connection to the April 28th death of Samantha Miller 34.  Miller, from Charlotte, North Carolina, was killed in the Folly Beach crash in Charleston County.  Three other of Miller's family members, including Hutchinson, suffered major injuries in the two-vehicle late evening crash.  The lawsuit also names five local businesses as defendants and claims Komoroski, 25, had been "bar hopping" the day of the wreck, which according to an arrest affidavit, involved a rented Toyota Camry slamming into the golf cart.  In addition to wrongful death, the 28-page suit also accuses the defendants of gross negligence, reckless hiring, supervision and training as well as "negligent infliction of emotional distress."  'Noticeably and visibly intoxicated'  A responding Folly Beach police officer, who found the victims on the ground at the scene, said the driver of the Camry smelled strongly of alcohol and admitted to drinking "one beer and a drink with tequila about an hour ago."  ‚ÄúDespite being noticeably and visibly intoxicated at each of these establishments,‚Äù the lawsuit reads, ‚ÄúJaime Komoroski continued to be served, provided, and/or allowed to consume alcohol in each of them.‚Äù  Former Raider enters plea in DUI caseEx-Raider Henry Ruggs pleads guilty to driving drunk at 156 mph, causing fatal crash  "This case is about keeping our community safe from drunk drivers, and an important part of that effort is making sure the establishments we entrust with liquor licenses live up to their responsibility to serve alcohol responsibly," the family's Charleston-based attorney Danny Dalton said.  The plaintiffs ask for a jury trial and seek punitive damages among other costs in connection to the case.  Just married  Earlier this month, Folly Beach Public Safety Department Chief Andrew Gilreath told USA TODAY Hutchinson and Miller were married just hours before the 10:15 p.m. wreck.  Police said data retrieved from Komoroski‚Äôs rental car show she was driving 65 mph and briefly hit the brakes before she slammed into the golf cart.  Komoroski, who is from Charleston, refused a sobriety and a breath test, according to her arrest affidavit. She was arrested and medical personnel drew a blood sample from her.  Prince Harry in harrowing "car chase"Prince Harry, Duchess Meghan say they were in 'near catastrophic' car chase with paparazzi  According to additional court papers, when her blood was drawn her Blood Alcohol Content was 0.261, more than three times the legal limit to drive.  She faces charges including reckless vehicular homicide and driving under the influence causing great bodily injury and is due in court next month for a hearing, court records show.  Komoroski's attorney could not immediately be reached by USA TODAY.  Natalie Neysa Alund covers breaking and trending news for USA TODAY. Reach her at nalund@usatoday.com and follow her on Twitter @nataliealund.

Getting engaged, planning a wedding, and preparing for life with your favorite person is one of the most exciting and joyful times of your life, but it can also be rife with familial conflicts, disagreements over the budget, and the need for a lot of compromises. Still, every challenge you face while planning your wedding is an opportunity to improve your relationship, strengthen your bond, and deepen your communication skills as a couple.  ‚ÄúDefining your shared values, navigating conflict, getting on the same page in terms of finances, deciding how we spend time in relationships outside of our primary relationships‚Äîany number of topics that come up during wedding planning need to get negotiated on an ongoing basis,‚Äù says Jennifer Uhrlass, licensed marriage and family therapist at Modern MFT in New York City. ‚ÄúIt has to be an ongoing, open dialogue, which is really training for the ongoing negotiations that are going that are going to take place along the course of the relationship.‚Äù  Meet the Expert Jennifer Uhrlass is a licensed marriage and family therapist (LMFT) at Modern MFT in New York City.  Ahead, Uhrlass speaks to us about how this crucial window of time‚Äîthe engagement period‚Äîcan be an opportunity for couples to strengthen their relationship and build new skills as partners.  Communicate and Compromise  Every aspect of your wedding is about the two of you as a couple, which means you‚Äôll both need to compromise to create a day that speaks to two different personalities. Sometimes it‚Äôs easy: Maybe one partner doesn‚Äôt care about the signature cocktails or the other partner doesn‚Äôt have a preference for the reception exit. But when only one partner is set on a destination wedding, or wants a religious ceremony, or won‚Äôt trim the guest list, the middle ground can be much harder to find.  The key, says Uhrlass, is making sure you take the time to fully listen to and process your partner‚Äôs wishes‚Äîand express your own‚Äîso that you can come to an agreement you are both on board with. ‚ÄúDo you truly, truly hear and understand the other person‚Äôs perspective, or are you just glossing over stuff and moving forward without understanding?‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThere are times when you can miss each other‚Äôs message‚Äîthe message sent is not always the message received. Recognize the importance of slowing down the interaction, making sure you heard and understood what your partner said, and making sure that you can come to a mutual understanding.‚Äù  Get Into an Argument‚Äîor Several  Arguments about the details of your wedding‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs your partner‚Äôs desire to torpedo the guest list by adding three tables of fraternity brothers or your own insistence on a specific type of music‚Äîare precursors to future conflicts in your life together. How you approach and solve these conflicts helps you lay the foundation for healthy and productive disagreements in the future. ‚ÄúLearning how to navigate conflict effectively with your partner is essential,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúYou have to be able to do that well with each other because the problems are going to be perpetual. There's always going to be a need to navigate and negotiate ongoing issues throughout the course of the relationship.‚Äù Today it‚Äôs the guest list and cake flavors; tomorrow it may be where to send your kids to school or how to spend your year-end bonus. ‚ÄúOften, partners tend to get caught up in the content of a disagreement, when it can be much more productive to focus on their process of engagement when it comes to a particular conflict,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs important is to learn how to navigate that conflict effectively; not so much trying to avoid conflict altogether, but to recognize that conflict is a healthy part of a relationship.‚Äù  Photo by Getty Images; Design by Mehroz Kapadia  Set Family Boundaries  Weddings can bring out the best in your family, but there's no denying that they can also bring out the worst. Explaining to your parents that you won‚Äôt be tying the knot at your childhood church, telling your mother-in-law her entire bridge club didn‚Äôt make the guest list, breaking the news to your siblings that their toddlers won‚Äôt be invited to the reception: These family conflicts (and many others) have the potential to put you and your partner on opposite teams. As you prepare for your wedding, it's important to remember that you‚Äôre also developing a new team of your own. ‚ÄúOne of the natural challenges around the topic of getting married is that there‚Äôs a shift: You were part of one family unit and now you‚Äôre cultivating a new family unit in your relationship with your partner,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúMoving through this identity shift can bring up a lot of conflicts and a lot of emotion.‚Äù  Use this time to set collective boundaries as a couple, understand each other‚Äôs family history, and prioritize your partnership. ‚ÄúIt is possible to work through this through dialogue and understanding each person‚Äôs perspective,‚Äù says Urhlass. ‚Äú‚ÄôYour mom wants this, however, for us, we‚Äôre also weighing this and this,‚Äô‚Äîyou want to make sure that you get on the same page so you can make decisions together as a unit.‚Äù  Talk About Money  How you choose to finance your wedding is a microcosm of the larger financial decisions you‚Äôll make in the future: How you put together a budget, and whether you‚Äôll stick to it; whether you‚Äôre willing to take on credit card debt or loans, or accept money from either set of parents; whether your individual incomes and spending patterns are causing unseen conflict. Deciding whether you want to splurge on a band or spend less on a DJ is a precursor to future conversations about which house is in your budget, whether you‚Äôll put a vacation on your credit card, and how often you need to upgrade your television. ‚ÄúNavigating issues related to finances is a common point of contention,‚Äù says Urhlass. ‚ÄúIt could bring up difficult emotions such as fear or feelings of inadequacy. There may also be significant power differentials; in a relationship where there's a disparity in income, it can negatively impact a couple's ability to address issues in a productive way. If partners haven't reached a place where they feel comfortable, there can be a lot to unpack there. If you're just leaving it festering in the background, and you're not really addressing it, then they will tend to get worse, or stay unaddressed, which can lead to contempt later on.‚Äù  Give Each Other Space to Destress  Every major life change brings a heightened period of stress, and you and your partner will need to know how to take care of yourselves‚Äîand each other‚Äîto get through them. ‚ÄúLearning to take care of yourself through the very difficult wedding planning process is, I think, an essential element to navigating life effectively,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúIf we're stressed to the max and we're not taking care of ourselves, we're not working out, we're not getting our proper sleep, we're not getting nutrition, or we're not spending time with friends, it‚Äôs going to have a major impact on how we approach topics and conflict and disagreements. It's really important to step back and stick to routines that are helpful to manage the stress effectively.‚Äù  This could mean planning your meal tasting around your partner‚Äôs weekly round of golf, making sure you have enough money set aside for weekend excursions (instead of putting all travel on hold until your honeymoon), or maintaining your Friday date night‚Äîno wedding talk allowed. ‚ÄúSet aside time to have space with each other,‚Äù says Uhrlass. ‚ÄúSpend time with each other nurturing your relationship, as opposed to talking about the to-do list for the wedding.  Define Your Shared Values  A shared vision for your big day can also help you define the elements that will become your family‚Äôs values moving forward: How closely will you follow religious traditions? How often will you see your parents and siblings? What constitutes a worthwhile financial investment? How do you, as a couple and as individuals, define and deepen your relationships with your friends? ‚ÄúTwo people can have very different beliefs and philosophies about money, or [anything] across the board,‚Äù says Urhlass. ‚ÄúThat doesn't necessarily mean that they're incompatible. It just might mean that there's more to talk about, that they understand each other and make sure that they can be on the same page in terms of their long-term goals, their values, and how they want to move forward in their lives developing a sense of identity as a couple.‚Äù

Why have the best wedding on Earth when you could have the best wedding in space? May 17, 2023 12:55 am | Updated 12:55 am IST - HYDERABAD  A 40-year-old man allegedly beat his wife to death and later took his own life, at Yellareddyguda in SR Nagar police limits in the wee hours of Tuesday.  Police said the woman, Premalatha, 35, was found bludgeoned to death with a rod. Reportedly, the incident took place after midnight, when the couple returned from the woman‚Äôs house in Thumkunta after their wedding anniversary celebrations. Their two children, who are in high school, were at the grandmother‚Äôs house in Thumkunta for the ongoing summer vacation.  It is suspected that Janardhan and Premalatha were engaged in a heated argument, which turned violent.  According to the police, Janardhan, an alcoholic, had left the family last year. After his wife, an employee at a dental clinic, filed a complaint, police traced him later in April.  Police shifted the bodies for post-mortem. An investigation is under way.  (Roshni, suicide prevention helpline: 81420-20033/ 81420-20044, from 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily)

Weddings are supposed to be joyful, but this joy can be accompanied by a lot of stress. Alongside choosing the menu, flowers and decorations and sorting the table plan, body image ‚Äì how we think and feel about the way we look ‚Äì can cause worries, too.  We could not identify any previous research that had formally looked at how brides in the UK felt about their body image. To address this, and fill the gap in our knowledge, our research explored how brides felt about their body image in the run-up to their wedding. We focused in particular on any appearance concerns that they had and how these made them feel ‚Äì from the planning stage right up to the big day itself.  One hundred and thirty-four women took part in either an interview or an online survey. They were a mix of women planning their weddings and those who had been married in the past three years. Many women experienced feelings of pressure and expectation to look a certain way on their wedding day.  This article is part of Quarter Life, a series about issues affecting those of us in our twenties and thirties. From the challenges of beginning a career and taking care of our mental health, to the excitement of starting a family, adopting a pet or just making friends as an adult. The articles in this series explore the questions and bring answers as we navigate this turbulent period of life.  You may be interested in:  Love Island ditches fast fashion: how reality celebrities influence young shoppers‚Äô habits  How to make your clothes last longer ‚Äì it‚Äôs good for your bank account and the environment too  It‚Äôs not just weddings ‚Äì how celebrating small wins and unconventional milestones can bring joy  They felt that this pressure came from various sources, including family and friends. They told us that others‚Äô perceptions of how they looked affected their own feelings, both on the wedding day and afterwards. One said:  If you know other people think you look nice then you have more confidence.  Another told us:  I didn‚Äôt want to feel ashamed of my appearance. I knew there would be a lot of attention and comments on it. Didn‚Äôt want to feel like I‚Äôd let people down‚Ä¶there were lots of questions about my appearance and dresses mainly from other women. It felt like how I looked was part of the ‚Äòdecoration‚Äô in the same way the table settings and order of service was.  Many of the women we spoke to felt the need to adhere to these pressures through fear of judgment and the expectation that all brides should look beautiful.  Looking back  The knowledge that wedding photographs and videos would provide permanent visual evidence of how they looked added to body image pressures. One said:  I wanted to look back at the photographs and feel 100% comfortable with what I saw.  The pressure felt by the women we spoke to also stemmed from the bridal industry, which perpetuates norms and assumptions about how brides should look. One woman, for example, talked about a bad experience she had in a bridalwear shop:  I felt the ladies in the dress shop were quite judgemental, saying I needed to eat better and basically lose weight, so I felt very negative towards me.  Nearly 70% of the women we spoke to who were planning their weddings intended to lose weight in preparation for their wedding day. The pressure to lose weight had a significant effect on their feelings and emotions. One said:  I‚Äôm really worried that preparing my weight for my wedding will re-trigger my anorexia and I don‚Äôt think people talk about the unnecessary pressure for brides and grooms to lose weight.  Some of the women reported going to extreme measures to achieve their weight-loss goals, including surgery. One had a gastric band fitted in the run-up to the wedding: this is a band around the stomach that limits its expansion, leading to feeling full sooner. Another had a tummy tuck ‚Äì cosmetic surgery to improve the shape of the stomach area.  Among the women we spoke to who were already married, only 27% had reached the weight they wanted to for their wedding. One said:  I was distressed when I realised I wouldn‚Äôt achieve this weight. I then felt fine approaching the day itself. However, I felt embarrassed after seeing photos of me and regretted getting married at my weight.  Our findings back up what other researchers have found in countries outside of the UK, such as in Australia and the US. This research has drawn attention to the powerful pressures related to wedding appearance and the expectation of how women should look when getting married.  If you are getting married, then it is completely natural for you to want to look your best, but prioritise your own wellbeing, too.  If one of your friends or family members is getting married, or if you work in the wedding industry, be conscious of what you are saying to the brides in your life. Make sure you are not inadvertently adding any pressures or expectations to them by commenting on their appearance during what can already be a stressful time. Focus on the joy and connection that is the real heart of a wedding.

Popular actress, Dalljiet Kaur tied the marital knot with UK-based businessman, Nikhil Patel, in a dreamy wedding ceremony on March 18, 2023. The actress had a second wedding, after her divorce from actor, Shalin Bhanot, and shifted to Nairobi, Kenya with her new family. Dalljiet has been settling into a new environment with her hubby, Nikhil Patel and their kids, Aariyana and Jaydon.  advertisement  Dalljiet Kaur reveals she and her hubby, Nikhil will go on a strict 8-month strict  In one of her vlogs, Dalljiet Kaur opened up about her married life and revealed how she is adjusting to a new place. Talking about the same, she shared that she and Nikhil ate everything unhealthy for the first month of their wedding, but now they will follow a strict 8-month diet regime. Revealing that they will eat the same food for 8 months, the actress said:  advertisement  "It has been a month since our marriage, and we had planned to eat everything unhealthy for the first month and enjoy the new place. After that, we are going for an 8-month strict diet regime with a healthy prepped meals diet with our trainer. We would be eating the same food for 8 months. This will be our last week of eating unhealthy food. There will be a complete plan counting our macros, calories, and proteins every day." Despite ominous black clouds and a thunderstorm warning issued by Environment Canada, Dominic and Alanis said their vows under the watchful gaze of the Dolphins, friends and family. Marnie says she is a friend of the groom, "they were actually supposed to be married during COVID, and instead had a very premature baby that took up their time."  Needless to say the wedding was postponed, but after the arrival of their second child in January, the couple decided to tie the knot this May. Cassie Parrott trims the stem of a flower as she creates an arrangement for a client last Wednesday at her home floral design studio in southwest Cedar Rapids. Parrott opened Parrott Floral Co. last year. (Jim Slosiarek/The Gazette)  CEDAR RAPIDS -- Cassie Parrott has expressed herself through flowers all of her adult life.  ‚ÄúFor me, it‚Äôs the creative side, and getting to share my artistic abilities through florals,‚Äù Parrott said one recent morning. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm horrible at drawing or painting or anything like that, but when it comes to being creative on the flower side...‚Äù  Parrott, 32, began working for florists soon after graduating from Cedar Rapids Jefferson High School, just a few blocks from her home. She kept working while completing Kirkwood Community College‚Äôs horticulture program.  Cassie Parrott creates a flower arrangement for a client at her Parrott Floral Co. home design studio last Wednesday in southwest Cedar Rapids. She opened her business last year. (Jim Slosiarek/The Gazette)  Advertisement  Gaining some 15 years experience, Parrott and her husband, Joey, decided last year it was time to strike out on her own.  ‚ÄúI had been doing it for other businesses and just decided I wanted to be doing it for myself,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI knew what it all entailed, and what I needed.‚Äù  A small toolshed in her backyard became her studio, freshened with new paint and outfitted with work tables and a florist‚Äôs refrigerator to keep blooms fresh.  ‚ÄúThankfully, we had this workshop,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt was just storage. We started converting, and it went really quickly after I decided I wanted to for-sure do it.‚Äù  Wedding specialty  Parrott‚Äôs goal is to specialize on weddings, but she‚Äôs taken other business during her start-up.  ‚ÄúFrom the beginning, I knew I was going to have to do some everyday retail,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúFriends and family will say, ‚ÄòHey, can you do a birthday bouquet for me tomorrow?‚Äô And I can make it happen.‚Äù  Business News Newsletter Signup Newsletter Signup Delivered to your inbox weekdays Email Please wait... Thank you for joining us! You will begin to receive our Daily Business News updates. Add newsletters@thegazette.com to your contacts.  Without a traditional storefront, which she didn‚Äôt want to invest in, Parrott typically begins the design process in customers‚Äô homes, where being a one-woman operation has its advantages.  ‚ÄúI have the capabilities and the time to actually get to know each one of my brides and give my undivided attention to them and not have to worry about other customers coming in,‚Äù she said.  Large, elaborate displays are popular for this season‚Äôs weddings, she said.  ‚ÄúBig, colorful arches and hanging installations,‚Äù Parrott said. ‚ÄúBig statement pieces are the trendy things right now.‚Äù  Most customers have at least some idea what they‚Äôre after.  ‚ÄúA lot of times they have somewhat of a vision,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôve gone to Pinterest or Google or Instagram or TikTok and found pictures they like. I guide them and make it fit within their budget and make their vision come to life for them.‚Äù  Cassie Parrott creates a flower arrangement for a client at her home floral design studio in Cedar Rapids. (Jim Slosiarek/The Gazette)  Using social media  Social media also is a key marketing tool.  ‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôre starting a business, anything free is helpful,‚Äù Parrott said. ‚ÄúAnytime we do a wedding and they post pictures and tag us in it, that helps spread the word.  ‚ÄúThose relationships with other wedding vendors help. A venue, a dress shop, a tux shop, a bakery, we all get together and make a mock wedding, and it‚Äôs photographed and we post that on our socials.‚Äù  Parrott works through a wholesale florist in Illinois and directly with big flower farms in Ecuador and Chile. In-season, she also buys locally grown blooms.  Managing deliveries, she said, is vital.  ‚ÄúWhen somebody‚Äôs buying a bouquet for a birthday or anniversary, they want that to last as long as possible. I want to get that in right before the occasion and get it out to them in the form where it‚Äôs barely started blooming,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWith a wedding, they‚Äôre wanting (the full bloom). Depending what kinds of blooms, I have a process where I get them to their full potential for the wedding day.‚Äù  Friends, family help  Parrott is her namesake company‚Äôs sole full-time employee, but friends and family help with deliveries and building elaborate arrangements. Peak wedding season brings some early-morning starts.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre always one of the first vendors at a wedding on Saturday,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou want to be in and out, so once they start with pictures that‚Äôs all done. By about noon I have everything set up.‚Äù  Cassie Parrott dyes flowers made out of wood shavings to create at floral arrangement for a client Wednesday at her home design studio in southwest Cedar Rapids. (Jim Slosiarek/The Gazette)  Despite working through the pandemic‚Äôs lingering supply-chain effects -- Parrott estimates wholesale flower costs have tripled -- she‚Äôs optimistic about her business‚Äô first busy season.  ‚ÄúWhen I opened, my main concern was just getting clients and getting my name out there as my business and myself,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôve booked 11 weddings since September. For my first eight months, that seems like a pretty good number.‚Äù

Everyone looks forward to Bollywood weddings because they are larger than life and an entire galaxy of stars come together to wish the couple well. However, there were also many B-town celebs who decided to keep their wedding an intimate affair. The trend of having a secret and hush-hush wedding also started after the Covid-19 pandemic.  But, did you know that ‚ÄòVivaah‚Äô actress Amrita Rao married the love of her life RJ Anmol at a temple in Pune on a budget as low as Rs 1,50,000?  View this post on Instagram A post shared by AMRITA RAO üáÆüá≥ (@amrita_rao_insta)  Recently, the couple released a YouTube video on their official channel wherein they elaborated on the cost of their wedding, the venue, and how they were able to pull off a close-knit shaadi in that budget.  In the ‚ÄòAnniversary Special‚Äô episode of ‚ÄòCouple Of Things‚Äô, they took us down memory lane to the place they got married nine years ago.  View this post on Instagram A post shared by RJ Anmol (@rjanmol27)  The handful of people who attended their wedding traveled from Mumbai to Iskcon Temple in Katraj, Pune where the couple secretly tied the knot. As for the stay and other functions like Sangeet, Mehendi, and Karaoke Night, the couple booked a hotel on the outskirts of Pune.  View this post on Instagram A post shared by RJ Anmol (@rjanmol27)  The couple further revealed that the outfits they wore were very traditional and cost not more than Rs 3000 each because they didn‚Äôt want to wear designer clothes. The ‚ÄòMain Hoon Na‚Äô actor also wore all artificial jewellery on her wedding day.  ‚ÄúWhen I told Anmol that I wanted to buy jewellery, he had told me ‚ÄòAbhi q shopping karni hai, tabhi karo na shaadi k baad.‚Äô And when the wedding happened, we were busy building our house so we had no time to shop. So, I wore artificial jewellery top to bottom. I was very angry.‚Äù  In the video, the couple then visited their wedding venue and relived those fond memories.  Amrita further revealed that she also carried her makeup kit and did her wedding makeup herself. Her family members helped her get ready for the special occasion.  They also added that one of the reasons they wanted to get married in Pune was because Amrita‚Äôs grandparents were in Pune so it was easier for them to travel to the venue. Concluding the video, Amrita shared:  ‚ÄúWe always believed that weddings should be about love, not about showing off wealth and ostentation. We wanted our wedding to be a beautiful, intimate affair with just our immediate families & close friends, and we‚Äôre glad we were able to achieve that without spending a fortune.‚Äù  To this, RJ Anmol added, ‚ÄúOur wedding was a reflection of our personalities, and we wanted to keep it humble. We would be happy if this inspires people to opt for budget-friendly weddings too.‚Äù  Clearly, you don‚Äôt have to spend crores to make memories and get married to the love of your life.  You can watch the entire video here:

The stage adaptation of ‚ÄúMonsoon Wedding,‚Äù the 2001 film by Mira Nair made its New York debut earlier this month. Based on a book by Arpita Mukherjee and Sabrina Dhawan, the musical is conceived and directed by Nair, and ‚Äútries to capture the 2001 film‚Äôs spirit,‚Äù according to The New York Times.  The past few months have been magnificent working as music producer to @MiraPagliNair Monsoon Wedding. Our 1st preview marched off Saturday and opening night is this coming Saturday. It‚Äôs truly a beautiful show. The show runs till June 25 and tickets are flying fast. pic.twitter.com/N1HwVgF8mc ‚Äî Sunny Jain (@sunnydrums) May 9, 2023  ‚ÄúMonsoon Wedding‚Äù follows the Vermas, a Punjabi family in Delhi busily preparing for a lavish wedding. As event planners string marigold flower chains and pitch a pole tent for the festivities, mania ensues. The bride-to-be, Aditi, is torn between her feelings for her ex-lover and her soon-to-be husband, the wedding planner falls in love with the family‚Äôs maid, and buried family secrets come to the surface during the days-long celebration. ‚ÄúNair‚Äôs celebration rings joyful and cathartic: as a love song to her home city of Delhi and to her own Punjabi family,‚Äù says the musical‚Äôs synopsis. ‚ÄúAt its core, it‚Äôs a story of families: how they love, rejoice, and endure together.‚Äù  calling all nyers and well wishers to immediately go see Mira Nair‚Äôs brilliant *Monsoon Wedding: The Musical* pic.twitter.com/twgjkJRP5n ‚Äî Manan Ahmed (@sepoy) May 14, 2023  The production was first staged in 2017 at Berkeley Repertory Theater, where it received mixed reviews, the Bay Area Player reported at the time. Work on the adaptation began in 2006, with Nair and the film‚Äôs screenwriter, Dhawan, collaborating with composer Vishal Bhardwaj and the lyricist Susan Birkenhead. Nair told The Times that ‚Äúshe‚Äôd been inspired by the 2004 Broadway revival of ‚ÄúFiddler on the Roof,‚Äù a show built around cultural traditions adapting to survive.  The Times further notes that ‚Äúlike the film, the musical touches upon the fallout of India‚Äôs 1947 partition, brought to life in the characters‚Äô religious, social and economic differences. Nair told the publication that the film is about ‚Äúour families, but so deeply universal ‚Äî this essential story of understanding a whole society and movement through a very personal story.‚Äù  However, the musical deviates a little from the film, in terms of messaging. For the musical, Nair had to revisit one of the film‚Äôs subplots, she told The Times, ‚Äúabout a relative‚Äôs grooming and sexual abuse of two younger family members.‚Äù A ‚Äúconcerted effort‚Äù was made to have ‚Äúthe women question the patriarchy and speak up,‚Äù Nair said. ‚ÄúOther characters who are afflicted by this don‚Äôt shove it under the rug; they make decisions in their own lives that reflect that they will not accept this behavior, which we didn‚Äôt have before.‚Äù  The change is reflective of Nair‚Äôs work which ‚Äúhas never shied away from examining cultural distinctions,‚Äù The Times notes. ‚ÄúMississippi Masala‚Äù (1991) explored the interracial romance between a Black man and Indian American woman, ‚ÄúSalaam Bombay!‚Äù (1988), revolved around children living in the slums.  ‚ÄúMonsoon Wedding‚Äù is currently playing at St. Ann‚Äôs Warehouse in Brooklyn, New York, through June 25.

Shabana Azmi, by her own admission, is playing an ‚Äúultra-glamorous‚Äù role in Karan Johar‚Äôs upcoming film Rocky Aur Rani Ki Prem Kahani. The actor, in a recent interview, said that she ‚Äúnever felt more beautiful on screen‚Äù and called it a ‚Äúliberating experience‚Äù.  In a chat with ETimes, Shabana recalled an incident from the time she was shooting for the film and had to attend a wedding after pack up. She shared that the attire that she was shooting in was befitting for a wedding so she attended the function in the same clothes and jewellery. ‚ÄúI remember in 2022 while shooting in Delhi for Rocky Aur Rani Ki Prem Kahani, I had to attend a wedding one evening. After the day‚Äôs shooting, I just took off wearing the saree and jewellery that I was shooting in,‚Äù she said.  Shabana Azmi shared that the film‚Äôs costume designer Manish Malhotra was ‚Äúhorrified‚Äù and said, ‚ÄúHow can you go to a wedding wearing shooting clothes and jewellery? At least let me give you real jewellery.‚Äù But Shabana asked him to ‚Äúrelax‚Äù as it would be completely fine. ‚ÄúAnd it was. I looked quite presentable at the wedding, if I may say so myself,‚Äù she added.  Rocky Aur Rani Ki Prem Kahani is Karan Johar‚Äôs next directorial. It marks his return as a director after 2016‚Äôs Ae Dil Hai Mushkil (Karan directed shorts in Lust Stories and Ghost Stories, respectively). The film, also starring Alia Bhatt, Ranveer Singh, Dharmendra, Jaya Bachchan, is scheduled to release on July 28.  In an earlier chat with Bollywood Life, Ranveer Singh described Rocky Aur Rani Ki Prem Kahani as a ‚Äúquintessential Karan Johar movie‚Äù and added, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs vintage Karan Johar, everything that you love about his films ‚Äì the songs, the glamour, the good-looking leads, the family dynamics, the pulpy drama, the humour, the romance, it‚Äôs all packed in there; every trope you‚Äôve seen in Karan Johar movies, his brand of cinema you have loved ‚Äì all there.‚Äù

A SELF-PROCLAIMED curvy girl planning a destination wedding has revealed a swimwear hack that provides a two-in-one vacation outfit.  The genius trick will also save you some space in your suitcase.  1 The trendy hack has been shared in a recent TikTok video Credit: TIKTOK/@trendycurvy  TikToker Kristine (@trendycurvy) shared her swimwear hack in a recent video.  "Its wedding week! Had to show y‚Äôall how to get the most out of your vacation wardrobe," she captioned the clip.  Kristine started her video in a two-piece black swimsuit with a floor-length kimono-style coverup.  "You need a duster like this for every vacation you go on," she said.  "First and foremost, it's a swimwear coverup," she continued.  But that's not its only purpose, Kristine said.  If you want to go to a nice dinner and need an extra outfit, the coverup can turn into a dress.  "Close this up, put a belt around it, some strappy heels, and you're good to go," she said.  "Two outfits in one."  Kristine's video has been viewed more than 105,000 times.  Manny offered congratulatory comments and some even asked where her swimsuit and coverup were from.  Meanwhile, another TikToker has shared the perfect bikini for a summer day at the beach.  Samantha Riehl showed the garment from the brand Sommer Swim to her more than 670,000 followers.  The bright red bikini comes with little silver accents and a unique rippling pattern along the waistband.

Erin McGregor has revealed she will not be opting for a church wedding when she walks down the aisle next year.  The influencer, and sister of UFC star Conor McGregor, is set to wed long-term partner Terry Kavanagh in 2024, with the pair documenting their search for the perfect venue on social media.  Today's top videos STORY CONTINUES BELOW  The mum-of-two did a recent Q&A [question and answer] on Instagram, with followers.  Erin McGregor has revealed she will not be opting for a church wedding when she walks down the aisle in 2024. Pic: Erin McGregor/Instagram  One follower asked the pair if they had decided between 'a wedding singer or music in the church?' prompting the duo to reveal they wouldn't be opting for a church wedding.  Erin answered: 'We don't want a church... do you want to say why we don't want a church?  'Eh, because of Harry,' Terry simply stated.  'So, Harry would feel better in an outdoor [setting] so it wouldn't be as overwhelming and the noise wouldn't be as intense for him,' Erin explained.  'Always worth the try' -- Erin McGregor shares realities of travelling with young son 'We want -- Har is our main man,' Terry added. Erin shared that six-year-old son Harry, who lives with autism, would be more comfortable outdoors, adding that he would be likely to want to leave a church setting.  'Yeah, so he can be part of it. Even if he wants to run off, he's still there where he'd probably want to leave a church.  'He likes the outdoors, so that works for us,' Terry said.  Turning their attention back to the question at hand, Erin asked her husband-to-be what type of music he wanted for their big day.  Erin shared that six-year-old son Harry, who lives with autism, would be more comfortable outdoors, adding that he would be likely to want to leave a church setting. Pic: Instagram/ Erin McGregor  'It depends on what song you want; it depends on the setting... do you know what I mean?' Terry said, prompting Erin to tease by branding him 'Groomzilla.'  'I'm talking about what you want!' he protested, as Erin ended the video.  The couple also lifted the lid on potentially eloping, with a follower revealing their friend eloped recently and it was 'zero stress.'  'I mean, it's been a long road,' Erin replied.  Erin and Terry have been bringing their followers along as they check out potential venues for their wedding, with the pair heading to Italy and Portugal with hopes of a wedding abroad. Pic: Instagram/ Erin McGregor  Erin and Terry have been bringing their followers along as they check out potential venues for their wedding, with the pair heading to Italy and Portugal.  Following a recent trip venue hunting in Sintra, Portgual, Erin told her Instagram followers that she thinks 'home is calling,' as she talked through the logistics of a wedding abroad.  'There is something about home as well that you're like, "I feel safe at home. I definitely feel safe at home."'

Monty Don is no stranger to muddy boots and gardening gloves, but he left them at home in exchange for much smarter attire as he attended a special family wedding.  The Gardeners' World star, 67, and his wife Sarah were pictured at their son's nuptials back in July 2020 ‚Äì which happened to be their own wedding anniversary. For the occasion, the pair proved their penchant for florals as they stepped out in summery outfits that may have been inspired by their Herefordshire garden, Longmeadow.  WATCH: Monty Don shares personal garden transformation  Monty offset his classic white shirt and black suit with a blue tie covered with yellow flowers, while Sarah tied in with his colour scheme in a stunning pastel blue frock. It featured a high neckline, long sleeves, a ditsy floral print and navy piping which she teamed with pearl drop earrings and her blonde hair in a sleek straight bob.  The celebrity gardener captioned the candid photo, which appears to have been taken at the wedding breakfast: "3 years ago on this day Sarah and I were celebrating our son Adam‚Äôs marriage to Emily. On the same day 37 years ago we were married too."  ¬© Instagram Monty and Sarah's son got married in 2017  At the time, fans rushed to comment on the couple's outfits, writing: "Look at you all poshed up," and: "I love the tie." A third added: "Lucky Monty, Sarah is a beauty."  Monty and Sarah chose much more timeless outfits on their own wedding day. On their 39th anniversary in 2022, he shared one rare throwback photo, taken in 1983, which showed the newlyweds standing outside a set of wrought iron gates, with Monty's new wife rocking an unconventional blue outfit.  Sarah ditched bridal white for a dusty cornflower jacket with large buttons down the front, which she paired with a chunky necklace and matching earrings.  Meanwhile, Monty didn't appear to have aged at all ‚Äì he sported the same thick curly hair and big grin and wore a cream suit and black spotty tie.  He accompanied the photo with a heartfelt message to his childhood sweetheart Sarah, whom he met at Cambridge University. "We got married 39 years ago today - the picture is a little faded, a little wrinkly, like us but the love is as evergreen and strong now as it was all those years ago," Monty sweetly wrote.  Monty and Sarah share three children, Tom, Adam and Freya, and they are proud grandparents to George and Daisy Rose. However, Sarah candidly opened up about her ill health following childbirth and the impact it had on their marriage in their book, The Jewel Garden.  "I was ill for months after our daughter was born despite having had a supposedly film-star birth at an enormously expensive private London hospital," Sarah wrote. "I had a slipped disc, a result of the bodged delivery, and was so anaemic that I needed a blood transfusion.  "My injuries were not acknowledged and as we tried to leave the hospital I had to walk down three flights of stairs because the lift had broken. I was unable to walk or stand properly for over a year," she shared.  Being bedridden put a strain on their relationship, with Sarah candidly writing: "When it came down to it, Montagu was a loony and I was ill all the time."  See more rare photos of Monty and Sarah...  ¬© Shutterstock Monty Don and his wife Sarah met at university  ¬© Richard Young/Shutterstock The couple got married in July 1986  ¬© Nick Harvey/Shutterstock They share three children, one of which got married on their anniversary  ¬© Jabphotography/Shutterstock Sarah and Monty often share photos of their garden at Longmeadow  MORE NEWS: Martin Freeman and girlfriend Rachel Mariam look so in love on red carpet  Planning your wedding? Sign up to HELLO!‚Äôs Bride Guide newsletter for expert advice, budget help, wedding inspiration and real life stories delivered straight to your inbox.
